docs.lead_paragraph: Emergency medical crews give medicine to as many as 800,000 Americans a year, but a new study suggests that many of the drugs are stored improperly. Researchers put temperature monitors in ambulances around the country and found that drugs used for heart attacks and other emergencies were routinely allowed to become too hot or too cold.

headline.main: Too Hot, Too Cold and Just Right

docs.abstract: Study by Dr Lawrence H Brown of SUNY Upstate Medical University that monitored storage temperatures in emergency vehicles finds 100% of cases studied breached recommended temperatures potentially rendering medicines less effective; cartoon (S)
docs.snippet: Emergency medical crews give medicine to as many as 800,000 Americans a year, but a new study suggests that many of the drugs are stored improperly.    Researchers put temperature monitors in ambulances around the country and found that drugs used...

docs.lead_paragraph: A pill to make you thin: it has long been a dieter's dream. But despite intense, if not desperate interest from the public -- 60 million Americans are obese -- and eagerness from drug companies to meet the demand, efforts to develop weight-loss drugs have been disappointing. The human body seems to guard its fat stores jealously, and attempts to outsmart the system often fail outright or backfire, causing dangerous side effects.

headline.main: Quest for Weight-Loss Drug Takes an Unusual Turn

docs.abstract: While many drug companies search for weight loss drugs, unintentional weight loss side effect is identified in several drugs that treat epilepsy and migraine headache; Zonegran and Topamax are now being tested for weight loss potential and some doctors are already prescribing them for their overweight patients; there are additional known side effects to therapy and weight loss varies, but some patients report drug gives them added motivation to lose more weight after moderate success aided by medication; chart; photos (L)
docs.snippet: A pill to make you thin: it has long been a dieter's dream.     But despite intense, if not desperate interest from the public -- 60 million Americans are obese -- and eagerness from drug companies to meet the demand, efforts to develop weight-loss...

docs.lead_paragraph: History's most famous superspreader was Typhoid Mary, born Mary Mallon in Ireland in 1869 and a cook for wealthy New York families. She was initially caught in 1906 when a sanitary engineer was hired to investigate six cases of typhoid fever in a banker's summer household in Oyster Bay, on Long Island.

headline.main: The Deadly Trails Of Typhoid Mary

docs.abstract: Description of life and trail of infection left by Mary Mallon, who was better known as Typhoid Mary and died in 1938 while still quarantined at Riverside Hospital (NYC); photo (S)
docs.snippet: History's most famous superspreader was Typhoid Mary, born Mary Mallon in Ireland in 1869 and a cook for wealthy New York families.    She was initially caught in 1906 when a sanitary engineer was hired to investigate six cases of typhoid fever in a...

docs.lead_paragraph: Specialists in eating disorders are constantly looking for new treatments. So the arrival of two new drugs that appear to curb food cravings and reduce appetite has piqued substantial interest. In the last few years, psychiatrists have been prescribing Topamax and Zonegran for people whose overeating meets the criteria for binge eating disorder, as well as for those with bulimia, who binge and then vomit, use laxatives or exercise to compensate.

headline.main: To Curb Cravings, and Maybe More

docs.abstract: Psychiatrists working with patients suffering from eating disorders have conducted several studies on use of Topamax and Zonegran to treat bulimia and episodes of binge eating; Dr Susan L McElroy, University of Cincinnati psychiatrist and lead author of Topamax study, found 94% of patients given Topamax significantly decreased binge frequency compared to 46% in control group and lost more weight than those given placebos; two drugs are not approved by Food and Drug Administration for eating disorders and drugs do cause side effects yet to be controlled; cartoon (S)
docs.snippet: Specialists in eating disorders are constantly looking for new treatments. So the arrival of two new drugs that appear to curb food cravings and reduce appetite has piqued substantial interest.    In the last few years, psychiatrists have been...

docs.lead_paragraph: I pick up my morning newspaper and flip directly to the sports pages because almost every article on Page 1 is about the war. I turn on the radio to get the traffic and weather reports only to hear that American troops have been hit by fire from their own side or that they have killed Iraqi civilians trying to escape the war zone. Throughout New York City and elsewhere, there are subtle reminders -- police officers carrying gas masks, soldiers with rifles at airports and toll booths -- that any of us at any time could be struck by another terrorist attack equal to the devastation of Sept. 11, or worse.

headline.main: Stress: It's Impossible to Avoid, but Possible to Conquer

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column acknowledges stressful time we live in and offers suggestions on ways to cope; Dr James Gordon, director of New York's Center for Mind-Body Medicine asserts that many physical manifestations of stress are normal; medical social worker Dr Barrie Cassileth, who is Memorial Sloan-Kettering integrative medicine director, works with patients facing life threatening disease and helps them cope with future; Gordon and Cassileth advise to control stress patients should stay well-informed, but avoid overexposure to stressful events; hold that such patients should also, seek out support, develop routines, exercise, prioritize, express themselves and create strong mind-body connections to enable relaxation and sense of control; cartoon (M)
docs.snippet: I pick up my morning newspaper and flip directly to the sports pages because almost every article on Page 1 is about the war. I turn on the radio to get the traffic and weather reports only to hear that American troops have been hit by fire from...

docs.lead_paragraph: A little-known operation restores hope for people who lose sight from chemical or heat burns of the eye or certain rare diseases. The procedure, 50 to 100 percent effective in healing corneal damage, is used worldwide, including Iran, where it helps restore sight for victims of Iraqi mustard gas attacks. A variation on corneal transplants, the surgery grafts stem cells from a donor or a patient's good eye to the injured eye. The cells are from the limbus, a rim around the cornea. The cells resheath the cornea's surface, the 50-micron-thick epithelium, to maintain it as a transparent window. When burns or disease wipe out the limbal stem cells, the epithelium clouds over with scar tissue, causing blindness.

headline.main: Stem Cell Transplants Offer New Hope in Some Cases of Blindness

docs.abstract: Dr Kenneth R Kenyon originates surgery that takes limbus stem cells, either from donor or patient's healthly eye, and grafts tissue to injured eye, producing improved vision; surgery has been used to help those injured in accidents, aniridics and Stevens Johnson patients, as well as for other conditions; success rate ranges from 50 to 100% effective, but critics argue long-term effects are not yet known; procedure is diagramed; drawing (L)
docs.snippet: A little-known operation restores hope for people who lose sight from chemical or heat burns of the eye or certain rare diseases. The procedure, 50 to 100 percent effective in healing corneal damage, is used worldwide, including Iran, where it helps...

docs.lead_paragraph: People with arthritis of the knee are often advised to exercise the muscle on the front upper part of the leg, the quadricep. But in a study released yesterday, researchers warned that such exercises did not seem to help and might even hasten the course of the disease. The report appears in Annals of Internal Medicine.
docs.abstract: Northwestern University researcher Dr Leena Sharma finds quadricep exercise can actually damage arthritic knees; new research points to benefit of maintaining muscle tone, rather than increasing muscle mass (S)
